questions.text: A 3-year-old child, while playing with a toy, suddenly developed swallowing difficulty and is crying excessively. The parents rushed the child to the emergency room, where an X-ray chest was conducted. The X Ray image is shown in the given picture. What is the best management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Based on the clinical scenario and the X Ray shown, the foreign body is inthe esophagus, and the management is Urgent Esophagoscopy

Foreign Body in Esophagus vs Airway


Explanation of Other Options:

Heimlich's Manoeuvre(Option A): Reserved for choking with complete airway obstruction. Not used in a conscious, crying child with an esophageal foreign body.

Urgent Bronchoscopy (Option C): Used for tracheobronchial foreign body, especially with cough, wheeze, or unilateral decreased air entry. Not needed if FB is in the esophagus.

Wait and Watch(Option D): Contraindicated in symptomatic patients - can lead to complications like perforation or aspiration. Only done in asymptomatic, distal FBs.

questions.text: A surgeon has planned a biopsy procedure for a supraglottic lesion. Before the procedure, he placed a cotton soaked in Xylocaine in the Pyriform Sinus region. Which nerve is being anesthetized?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Before a biopsy of a supraglottic lesion, local anesthesia is often required to suppress the gag and cough reflex. Placing a cotton swab soaked in Lidocaine in the pyriform sinus is a technique used to anesthetize the internal laryngeal nerve, which supplies the mucosa of the supraglottic larynx and pyriform sinus.

Internal laryngeal nerve: Sensory branch of the superior laryngeal nerve; supplies supraglottic larynx, base of tongue, epiglottis, and pyriform sinus

Explanation of Other Options:

Superior laryngeal nerve(Option A): The superior laryngeal nerve, a branch of the vagus nerve, produces two branches, the internal laryngeal nerve (its sensory branch), which supplies sensory fibers to the laryngeal mucosa, and the external laryngeal nerve (its motor branch), which innervates the cricothyroid muscle. Local anesthetic injections to block the superior laryngeal nerve (SLN) can anesthetize the supraglottic region, down to the bottom of the epiglottis, and block the cricothyroid muscle, which relaxes the vocal cords, not the specific branch anesthetized.

External laryngeal nerve(Option B): Motor to cricothyroid muscle (tenses vocal cords); no sensory role in supraglottis

Recurrent laryngeal nerve(Option D): Motor to all intrinsic laryngeal muscles (except cricothyroid); sensory to infraglottic region (below vocal cords)

questions.text: A 45-year-old obese male presents with loud snoring, daytime sleepiness, and episodes of observed apnea during sleep. The ENT surgeon discusses management options. Which of the following is not considered a treatment modality?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Based on the clinical scenario, the most probable diagnosis would be Obstructive sleep apnea. Muller's maneuver is used in the diagnosis of OSA and has no role in treatment

Muller's manoeuvre

  • An endoscope is used to look for collapse of soft tissues in the oropharynx when the patient inspires vigorously.
  • Levels of pharyngeal obstruction can be found.
  • It plays a role in the diagnosis of obstructive sleep apnea but has no role in its treatment.

Obstructive sleep apnea:

OSA is characterized by repetitive episodes of complete or partial obstruction of the upper airway during sleep, leading to cessation (apnea) or reduction (hypopnea) of airflow despite ongoing respiratory effort.

Etiology & Risk Factors:

  • Obesity (most common)
  • Enlarged tonsils/adenoids (especially in children)
  • Macroglossia (e.g., in acromegaly)
  • Nasal obstruction (e.g., deviated septum, polyps)
  • Retrognathia or craniofacial abnormalities
  • Alcohol, sedatives, and smoking

Diagnosis:

  • Polysomnography (Sleep Study): Gold standard
    • Measures apneas/hypopneas per hour (AHI: Apnea-Hypopnea Index)
    • Mild: 5-15/hr, Moderate: 15-30/hr, Severe: >30/hr
  • Müller's Manoeuvre
    • Diagnostic tool performed during nasopharyngoscopy
    • Identifies the level of pharyngeal collapse to guide surgical planning
  • Cephalometric X-rays / CT / MRI
    • To assess structural causes (optional)

Treatment options for OSA:

A. Lifestyle changes

  • Weight loss(Option A ruled out)
  • Quit alcohol and smoking
  • Dietary modification

B. Positional therapy: Sleeping on the side, as the supine position may cause OSA.

C. CPAP(Continuous Positive Airway Pressure) or BiPAP(bilevel positive airway pressure) when CPAP is not tolerated. These devices maintain a positive pressure and keep the airway open. (Option B ruled out)

D. Surgical: Laser Uvulopalatopharyngoplasty(UPPP) - The aim is to increase the size of the airway. (Option C ruled out)

choices.text: Lies posterior to the cricoid cartilage; part of the hypopharynx, often involved in dysphagia in post-radiation cases.
A Common site for nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

questions.text: Identify the anatomical area marked with the arrow
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The arrow points to the Fossa of Rosenmuller, which is the common site for nasopharyngeal carcinoma

The image shown is of the lateral wall of the nasopharynx.

  • The pharyngeal opening of the eustachian tube is situated 1.25 cm behindthe posterior end of the inferior turbinate.
  • It is bounded above and behind by an elevation called torus tubarius,raised by the cartilage of the tube.
  • Above and behind the tubal elevation is a recess called the fossa of Rosenmüller, which is the most common site for the origin of nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

Explanation of Other Options:

Common site of hypopharyngeal cancers(Option A): Pyriform sinus. This is a mucosal recess in the hypopharynx, lateral to the aryepiglottic fold, and is frequently visualized during laryngoscopy.

Boundaries

  • Lateral - Thyrohyoid membrane and the thyroid cartilage
  • Medial - Aryepiglottic fold, posterolateral surfaces of arytenoid and cricoid cartilages.

Lies posterior to the cricoid cartilage( Option B): part of the hypopharynx, often involved in dysphagia in post-radiation cases- Postcricoid area, Posterior part of hypopharynx, behind the larynx

Key landmark for intubation(Option C): Vallecula, more anterior and superior, between the tongue and epiglottis, not lateral.

choices.text: From the pharyngeal tubercle of the occipital bone to the level of the sixth cervical vertebra
From the posterior nasal spine to the inferior border of the thyroid cartilage
From the sphenoid sinus to the body of the hyoid bone
From the choanae to the lower border of the epiglottis

questions.text: During a preoperative briefing, an ENT resident is asked about the full anatomical extent of the pharynx to ensure complete visualization during fiberoptic nasal endoscopy. Which of the following best describes the anatomical boundaries of the pharynx?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The appropriate answer would be from the pharyngeal tubercle of the occipital bone to the level of the sixth cervical vertebra

The pharynx extends from the base of the skull(basioccipital and basisphenoid) to the lower border of the cricoid cartilage. (C6 Vertebral Level)

  • It is a conical fibromuscular tube forming the upper part of the air and food passages.
  • It is 12-14 cm long
  • Narrowest at pharyngo-oesophageal junction. - Cricopharyngeal Sphincter(C6 Level)

The pharynx is divided into 3 parts:

  • Nasopharynx- extending from the skull base to the soft palate, which lies opposite to C1
  • Oropharynx- extends from the soft palate to the hyoid bone, which lies opposite C2 and upper C3
  • Hypopharynx- extends from the hyoid to the lower border of the cricoid, which lies opposite C3-C4

Explanation of Other Options:

From the posterior nasal spine to the inferior border of the thyroid cartilage(Option B): This is incorrect because the posterior nasal spine lies in the hard palate, not at the upper limit of the pharynx, and the pharynx extends below the thyroid cartilage to the level of the cricoid cartilage at C6.

From the sphenoid sinus to the body of the hyoid bone(Option C): Although the sphenoid sinus is near the nasopharynx and the hyoid bone corresponds to the oropharyngeal level, this range excludes the lower third of the pharynx-the laryngopharynx-which extends beyond the hyoid bone.

From the choanae to the lower border of the epiglottis(Option D): This statement limits the pharynx to only the nasopharynx and part of the oropharynx; the actual lower limit of the pharynx lies much farther down, at the level of the cricoid cartilage (C6), beyond the epiglottis.
